V, MEMBER SERVICES
Engineering Service
The NAEB Engineering Service, started July 1, 1954 under a grant from
the FAE, and later made possible by grants from the Ford Foundation, was
also a service called for and endorsed by the other organizations in the move¬
ment „
The Center did not wish to dissipate its program concentration by
becoming involved in general technical station problems. The JCET's Engineer¬
ing Consultant did not feel qualified to get into the technical area of station
installation and operation, limiting himself to broader aspects of the national
structure, assisting in preliminary planning, and facilitating license and other
procedures through Washington contacts with the FCC and other such groups.
The work of the NAEB Engineering service began where the JCET ser¬
vice left off, with implementation and operational problem assistance. In all
cases we believe the cooperation which existed among the NAEB, the JCET and
the Center's engineering personnel, exemplify inter-agency cooperation and
assistance of the highest order.
The NAEB TV Engineer gave advice on the selection of television equip¬
ment; helped with station planning, staff training and operational problems;
followed the technical development of new broadcast equipment and whan in¬
dicated, prepared special reports on new equipment for the guidance of ETV
stations and those planning stations. We believe his efforts resulted in
savings of considerable magnitude, improved installations and output consid¬
